facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 11 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated 20 June 1950 of High Court of Punjab at Simla in Regular First Appeal No. 73 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and Decree dated the 20th day of June 1950 of the High Court of Judicature for the State of Punjab at Simla in Regular First Appeal No. 73 of 1941 arising out of the Decree

facts.text: High Court affirmed decree dated 19 December 1940 of Sikh Gurdwaras Tribunal, Lahore in Suit No. 11 of 1938 dismissing the suit.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the Decree dated the 19th day of December 1940 of the Sikh Gurudaras Tribunal, Lahore in Suit No. 11 of 1938. Gurbachan Singh and R. S. Narula, for the appellant.

facts.text: Plaintiff is Committee of Management of Sikh Gurdwaras within Municipal limits of Amritsar except Gurdwara Sri Akal Takhat Sahib.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff in the appeal is the Committee of Management of Sikh Gurdwaras within the Municipal limits of Amritsar  except the Gurdwara Sri Akal Takhat Sahib, Amritsar .

facts.text: Plaint filed under section 25-A of Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925 for possession of properties declared Sikh Gurdwara by notification No. 9-G dated 3 March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint was filed under section 25-A of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925,  Punjab Act VIII of 1925   hereinafter referred to as the Act  for possession of certain properties situated in Amritsar, marked and bounded as specified in the plaint and purporting to have been declared as a Sikh Gurdwara by the Government of Punjab under section 17 of the Act by means of the numberification No. 9-G dated the 3rd March, 1937.

facts.text: Properties determined to be Sikh Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar by Tribunal decree dated 4 November 1935, confirmed by High Court Lahore on 16 June 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the plaintiff-Committee is that these properties were, and were determined to be, a Sikh Gurdwara, by name Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar, by the Sikh Gurdwara Tribunal by its decree dated the 4th November, 1935 and companyfirmed on appeal therefrom by the High Court of Judicature at Lahore, on the 16th June, 1936

facts.text: Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee filed list under section 3 claiming suit properties as belonging to Gurdwara Harmandir Sahib within one year of Act's commencement.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act was passed and within one year of its companymencement the then existing number-statutory Shiromani Gur- dwara Parbandhak Committee filed a list under section 3 of the Act claiming the suit properties and certain other items attached thereto as belonging to the Gurdwara Harmandir Sahib.

facts.text: Properties comprised Bunga Sarkar, Bunga Mai Mallan and appurtenant shops.

anchor.surface_text: These properties companyprised two items called Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan and the shops appurtenant to each of them.

facts.text: Objections filed under section 8: Sardar Balwant Singh on 8 March 1928, Sardar Raghbir Singh on 10 March 1928 claiming as private properties.

anchor.surface_text: Objections were filed to this list by way of two applications under section 8 of the Act claiming these as private properties. One was by Sardar Balwant Singh dated the 8th March., 1928 and the other was by Sardar Raghbir Singh dated the 10th March, 1928.

facts.text: Parties entered compromise on 6 February 1930: some items private property, rest wakf bungas for Yatries to Sri Darbar Sahib, managed by claimants.

anchor.surface_text: The parties to these -proceedings entered into a companypromise on the 6th february, 1930. There were two companypromises one relating to each of the applications. The net effect of the companypromises was that some out of the items claimed were admitted to be the private property of the respective claimants and the rest as wakf bungas for the Yatries to Sri Darbar Sahib, that the number-personal properties were to remain in the management of the claimants, their heirs and representatives as such wakf with certain stipulations as to how that management was to be carried on.

facts.text: Tribunal disposed applications per compromises.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal disposed of the two applications before them in terms of these companypromises.

facts.text: Petition under section 7 filed by 55 Sikhs claiming properties as Sikh Gurdwara Bunga Sarkar Maharaja Ranjit Singh Saheb, prior to section 3 list.

anchor.surface_text: Now, quite independently of these proceedings befere the Tribunal, and prior to the filing of the list under section 3 and of the objections under section 5 above referred to, there had been filed a petition under section 7 of the Act, signed by 55 Sikhs, claiming these very properties as being in themselves a Sikh Gurdwara by name Bunga Sarkar  Maharaja Ranjit Singh Saheb  and enclosing a list of properties as belonging thereto under section 7 2  -of the Act.

facts.text: Government issued notification under section 7(3) on 18 February 1930.

anchor.surface_text: The petition under section 7 was in the usual companyrse followed by a numberification issued by the Government on the 18th February, 1930, under section 7 3  of the Act.

facts.text: Objections: Granthis under s.8 that not Sikh Gurdwara; Raghbir Singh and Balwant Singh under s.10 on 5 April 1930 claiming private properties.

anchor.surface_text: This resulted in  1  an objection under section 8 by the Granthis objecting that this was number a Sikh Gurdwara, and  2  two other objections by Sardar Raghbir Singh and Sardar Balwant Singh, already previously above referred to, under section 10 of the Act claiming the properties as their own and objecting to the claim made that they were Sikh Gurdwaras. These objections were filed on the 5th April, 1930.

facts.text: Tribunal declared Bunga Sarkar a Sikh Gurdwara on 28 August 1935 against Granthis objection.

anchor.surface_text: after recording some evidence, the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that Bunga Sarkar was a Sikh Gurdwara and declared it as such on the 28th August, 1935.

facts.text: Tribunal decision 4 November 1935: some properties personal to Raghbir and Balwant Singh, rest Sikh Gurdwaras appurtenant to Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan, vested in their management per compromises.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by its decision dated the 4th November, 1935, decided that the properties which had been declared as the properties of Sardar Raghbir Singh and Sardar Balwant Singh respectively, should be declared to be their personal properties and that the rest of the properties claimed to belong to Bunga Sarkar and Bunga Mai Mallan should be declared to be Sikh Gurdwaras and as properties appurtenant thereto. It was also declared that these two Gurdwaras and the properties held to be appurtenant to them should vest in the management of Sardar Raghbir Singh and Sardar Balwant Singh by virtue of and as per terms of the companypromises.

facts.text: High Court on appeal 16 June 1936 deleted management direction from Tribunal decree, affirmed rest, noted Bunga Mai Mallan part of Bunga Sarkar.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court without giving any decision on the legal question so raised was of the opinion that it was numberfunction of the Sikh Gurdwara Tribunal to pass an order on an application made under section 10 by the claimants that the claimants should manage the properties appurtenant to the Gurdwaras by virtue of the companypromises. ... This decision of the High Court was on the 16th June, 1936.

facts.text: Notification No. 9-G under section 17 dated 3 March 1937 issued.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by numberification No. 9-G dated the 3rd March, 1937, under section 17 of the Act which is the foundation of the present suit.

facts.text: Suit under section 25-A filed on 25 February 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit has been filed on the 25th February, 1938, i.e., clearly beyond one year of the decision.

facts.text: Plaintiff Committee constituted prior to 1930, functioning at time of 6 February 1930 compromises.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the present plaintiff which is the Committee of Management for all the Gurdwaras situated within the Municipal limits of Amritsar, except the Gurdwara Sri Akal Takht Sahib was companystituted prior to the year 1930 and was in fact functioning at the date of the companypromises in the section 5 proceedings dated the 6th February, 1930.

facts.text: Supreme Court held suit barred by limitation under section 25-A as filed more than one year after High Court decision on 16 June 1936 and after constitution of Committee.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.

facts.text: Sardar Balwant Singh died during pendency of appeal in High Court, legal reps not brought on record timely, appeal abated.

anchor.surface_text: The whole appeal abated in the High Court inasmuch as one of the respondents, Sardar Balwant Singh died during the pendency of the appeal. His legal representatives were number brought on record in time

facts.text: Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and Managing Committee entered compromises in s.5 proceedings without disclosing s.7 petition.

anchor.surface_text: The companyduct of the Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and the companycerned Committee of Management, in entering into the companypromises in the proceedings under section 5 of the Act without disclosing the pendency of the petition filed by the 55 Sikhs under section 7 of the Act

facts.text: Committees declined to become parties in s.10 proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On the objections under section 10 numberices were given to the Committee of Manaaement as well as to the Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee but they declined to become parties to it.

facts.text: Suit No. 11 of 1938 filed before Sikh Gurdwaras Tribunal.

The plaint was filed under section 25-A of the Sikh Gurdwaras Act, 1925,  Punjab Act VIII of 1925   hereinafter referred to as the Act  for possession of certain properties situated in Amritsar, marked and bounded as specified in the plaint and purporting to have been declared as a Sikh Gurdwara by the Government of Punjab under section 17 of the Act by means of the notification No. 9-G dated the 3rd March, 1937.

Now, quite independently of these proceedings before the Tribunal, and prior to the filing of the list under section 3 and of the objections under section 5 above referred to, there had been filed a petition under section 7 of the Act, signed by 55 Sikhs, claiming these very properties as being in themselves a Sikh Gurdwara by name Bunga Sarkar  Maharaja Ranjit Singh Saheb  and enclosing a list of properties as belonging thereto under section 7 2  -of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: 3  Any such decision would be contrary to section 37 of the Act and also contrary to the principles of res judicata and would be, therefore, a nullity on that ground.

4  The conduct of the Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and the concerned Committee of Management, in entering into the compromises in the proceedings under section 5 of the Act without disclosing the pendency of the petition filed by the 55 Sikhs under section 7 of the Act, followed up by their declining to be made parties in the section 10 proceedings and in virtually promoting the contest of the proceedings under sections 8 and 10, was fraudulent. They are accordingly estopped from relying on the decree obtained under section 10 proceedings and basing their right to relief thereon.
3  Any such decision would be contrary to section 37 of the Act and also contrary to the principles of res judicata and would be, therefore, a nullity on that ground.

Though we have heard elaborate arguments from both sides on these various contentions, it appeared to us ultimately that the plea of limitation is decisive against the appellants and that it is unnecessary to express any opinion on any of the other contentions raised.

issues.text: Whether the proceedings under section 10 resulted in any specific declaration that the properties in dispute constituted a Sikh Gurdwara or belonged to a Sikh Gurdwara

anchor.surface_text: 1  The proceedings under section 10 did number result in any specific declaration in favour of the Committee that the properties in dispute in the present suit companystituted a Sikh Gurdwara or belong to a Sikh Gurdwara. No such declaration can-be gathered from the decision of the Tribunal dated the 4th November, 1935, or from that of the High Court on appeal dated the 16th June, 1936.

issues.text: Whether the Tribunal had jurisdiction under section 10 to give a positive declaration that the property is a Sikh Gurdwara

anchor.surface_text: 2  The Tribunal had numberjurisdiction in disposing of an application under section 10 of the Act, to give a positive declaration that the property in question is a Sikh Gurdwara. Its only function was to decide whether or number the properties claimed were the private properties of the claimants.

issues.text: Whether any such decision would be contrary to section 37 of the Act and principles of res judicata, rendering it a nullity

anchor.surface_text: 3  Any such decision would be companytrary to section 37 of the Act and also companytrary to the principles of res judicata and would be, therefore, a nullity on that ground.

issues.text: Whether the conduct of the Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and Committee of Management was fraudulent, estopping them from relying on the section 10 decree

anchor.surface_text: 4  The companyduct of the Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and the companycerned Committee of Management, in entering into the companypromises in the proceedings under section 5 of the Act without disclosing the pendency of the petition filed by the 55 Sikhs under section 7 of the Act, followed up by their declining to be made parties in the section 10 proceedings and in virtually promoting the companytest of the proceedings under sections 8 and 10, was fraudulent. They are accordingly estopped from relying on the decree obtained under section 10 proceedings and basing their right to relief thereon.

issues.text: Whether suit under section 25-A lies only where decision on objection under section 10 is after notification declaring the Gurdwara as Notified Sikh Gurdwara

anchor.surface_text: 5  The suit under section 25-A lies only where the decision on an objection under section 10 1  is reached after the numberification that the Gurdwara is a Sikh Gurdwara is published since the section refers to. a decision in favour of a Notified Sikh Gurdwara implying the pre-existence of such numberification.

issues.text: Whether the suit under section 25-A was barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: 6  The suit under section 25-A was barred by limitation.

issues.text: Whether the appeal abated in the High Court due to death of respondent Sardar Balwant Singh without timely substitution of legal representatives

anchor.surface_text: 7  The whole appeal abated in the High Court inasmuch as one of the respondents, Sardar Balwant Singh died during the pendency of the appeal. His legal representatives were number brought on record in time and the High Court declined to excuse the delay and to set aside the abatement, as a result of which the entire appeal abated, the claim against both the respondents being joint and number being maintainable against one only in the absence of the other.

issues.text: Whether the notification under section 7(3) was ultra vires as section 7 assumes existence of a Gurdwara
Whether the suit was filed within one year from the date of constitution of the Committee concerned

anchor.surface_text: The question for companysideration, therefore, is whether the suit can be said to have been within one year from the date of the companystitution of the Committee of the Gurdwara companycerned.

arguments.claim: Plaintiff is entitled to possession of the properties under section 25-A based on the High Court judgment dated 16 June 1936 declaring the properties as Sikh Gurdwaras and the subsequent notification under section 17 dated 3 March 1937.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, the case for the plaintiff is quite simple. The plaintiff says that whatever may be the position with reference to the earlier compromises arrived at between the parties in the proceedings under section 5 of the Act, the later proceedings with reference to those very properties under section 10 of the Act resulted in the judgment of the High Court dated the 16th June 1936, which is conclusive and binding.

arguments.claim: The proceedings under section 10 did not result in any specific declaration that the properties constituted a Sikh Gurdwara or belonged to a Sikh Gurdwara.

anchor.surface_text: 1  The proceedings under section 10 did not result in any specific declaration in favour of the Committee that the properties in dispute in the present suit constituted a Sikh Gurdwara or belong to a Sikh Gurdwara. No such declaration can-be gathered from the decision of the Tribunal dated the 4th November, 1935, or from that of the High Court on appeal dated the 16th June, 1936.

arguments.claim: Tribunal had no jurisdiction under section 10 to give positive declaration that property is Sikh Gurdwara; only to decide if private properties of claimants.

anchor.surface_text: 2  The Tribunal had no jurisdiction in disposing of an application under section 10 of the Act, to give a positive declaration that the property in question is a Sikh Gurdwara. Its only function was to decide whether or not the properties claimed were the private properties of the claimants.

arguments.claim: Any such decision declaring properties as Sikh Gurdwara would be contrary to section 37 and res judicata, hence nullity.

anchor.surface_text: 3  Any such decision would be contrary to section 37 of the Act and also contrary to the principles of res judicata and would be, therefore, a nullity on that ground.

arguments.claim: Conduct of Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and Management Committee was fraudulent by entering compromises without disclosing section 7 petition, declining to be parties in section 10, promoting contest; estopped from relying on section 10 decree.

anchor.surface_text: 4  The conduct of the Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee and the concerned Committee of Management, in entering into the compromises in the proceedings under section 5 of the Act without disclosing the pendency of the petition filed by the 55 Sikhs under section 7 of the Act, followed up by their declining to be made parties in the section 10 proceedings and in virtually promoting the contest of the proceedings under sections 8 and 10, was fraudulent.

arguments.claim: Suit under section 25-A lies only where decision on section 10 objection is after notification declaring Gurdwara as Notified Sikh Gurdwara, implying pre-existing notification.

anchor.surface_text: 5  The suit under section 25-A lies only where the decision on an objection under section 10 (1) is reached after the notification that the Gurdwara is a Sikh Gurdwara is published since the section refers to. a decision in favour of a Notified Sikh Gurdwara implying the pre-existence of such notification.

arguments.claim: Suit under section 25-A barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: 6  The suit under section 25-A was barred by limitation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Suit filed 25 Feb 1938, more than one year after HC decision 16 Jun 1936 and committee constitution pre-1930.

arguments.claim: Appeal abated in High Court due to death of respondent Sardar Balwant Singh without timely bringing legal representatives on record; entire appeal abated as joint claim.

anchor.surface_text: 7  The whole appeal abated in the High Court inasmuch as one of the respondents, Sardar Balwant Singh died during the pendency of the appeal. His legal representatives were not brought on record in time and the High Court declined to excuse the delay and to set aside the abatement, as a result of which the entire appeal abated, the claim against both the respondents being joint and not being maintainable against one only in the absence of the other.

arguments.claim: Committee concerned with suit Gurdwara only from notification under section 17 (3 March 1937); limitation under section 25-A runs one year from then; pre-existing committee deemed constituted on notification date per policy of sections 86 and 88.
arguments.court_reasoning: Section 86 not applicable to Amritsar Gurdwaras under s.85; s.88(2) deeming provision fixes constitution date at notification of members, pre-1930; cannot imply other date.

arguments.claim: Suit under section 25-A barred by limitation as filed more than one year after High Court decision dated 16 June 1936 and constitution of committee under section 85 prior to 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Though we have heard elaborate arguments from both sides on these various contentions, it appeared to us ultimately that the plea of limitation is decisive against the appellants and that it is unnecessary to express any opinion on any of the other contentions raised. ... We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.

arguments.claim: Notification under section 7(3) ultra vires as section 7 assumes pre-existing Gurdwara; prior section 5 compromises negate existence.

holdings.text: The present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit filed on 25 Feb 1938, more than one year after High Court decision dated 16 Jun 1936 disposing of s.10 proceedings and after constitution of relevant Committee under s.85 prior to 1930; s.25-A limits suit to one year from decision or Committee constitution, whichever later.

holdings.text: The date of the decision under s.25-A(1) is the date of High Court judgment on appeal from Tribunal in s.10 proceedings, i.e., 16 June 1936.

anchor.surface_text: Now the date of the decision in this case must be taken to be the date when the High Court on appeal disposed of the proceedings under section 10, i.e., the 16th June, 1936.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court appeal finally disposed of s.10 objections; that is the relevant 'decision' for limitation start.

holdings.text: The plaintiff Committee under s.85 was constituted prior to 1930 and functioning by 6 Feb 1930; date deemed per s.88(2) as notification publication of members.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed fact; s.85 covers Amritsar municipal Gurdwaras; s.88(2) deems constitution date as notification of members.

holdings.text: Contention that Committee constitution for limitation under s.25-A should be deemed as date of s.17 notification (3 Mar 1937) is untenable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.86 applies only to Gurdwaras other than those in s.85 (Amritsar); s.88(2) deeming provision mandatory, cannot imply alternative date or exception as that would be legislating.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to express any opinion on the other contentions raised as limitation is decisive.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation plea sufficient to dispose appeal; other issues (i1-i5,i7,i8) left undecided.

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the opinion that the present suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation and on this ground the appeal must fail.

outcome.relief_summary: The suit under section 25-A is barred by limitation; the appeal must fail
